title: Koala Rescue Adelaide Hills use coats to keep koalas warm like Danny
text:
It’s not natural for koalas to go naked but that’s exactly the slippery situation Danny here has found himself in.

Danny was rescued by Adelaide & Hills Koala Rescue earlier this month when he was found covered in oil after he wandering into a Williamstown workshop and tangling with a full drip tray.

Nicknamed for the equally oily Danny Zuko of Grease fame, Danny left rescuers with few options.

media_camera Danny the Koala has to wear coats in order to stay warm after getting himself covered in oil, forcing a very short haircut. Picture: Simon Cross media_camera Danny does not enjoy nudity. Picture: Simon Cross

So out came the clippers and off came Danny’s coat.

“The oil suffocates them because it gets into their skin,” Adelaide & Hills Koala Rescuevolunteer Sally Sellwood said.

But, Ms Sellwood said Danny is not the only koala who will find himself without a suitable wardrobe this summer.

Adelaide & Hills Koala Rescue has appealed for coat donations to protect rescued koalas that could be burned by bushfires after South Australia authorities brought forward this years fire season due to a dry winter.

media_camera Danny the Koala. Picture: Simon Cross media_camera Danny the Koala. Picture: Simon Cross

And following major koala rescue efforts in previous fires like the 2015 bushfires around Pinery in the state’s mid north, and Sampson Flat, in the northern hills, rescuers are steeling for a tough summer.

“We’re expecting an even worse fire season than last year,” Ms Sellwood said.

media_camera Danny will unfortunately be the first of many koalas who rely on donated clothing if predictions of a dangerous bushfire season are realised. Picture Simon Cross

“A lot of [koalas] are burned … even if they don’t get burned from the fires they get burned from the warm tree or they get burned from ground that’s been burned.

Even indirect heat could leave them with damaged coats.

Without their coat, Ms Sellwood said, koalas can’t be sent back into the wild because they can develop hyperthermia and pneumonia.

“We want to keep them warm because they do get quite cold when they’ve been burnt.”

media_camera Danny the Koala rugged up at Adelaide and Hills Koala Rescue in Victor Harbor. Picture Simon Cross

Dog coats and jackets made of cotton or fleece are perfect so koalas don’t get their claws caught in the fabric, she said.

The Flinders, Mid North, Yorke Peninsula, Riverland and Murraylands regions will have their fire season start two weeks early after a dry winter.

Coats can be donated to help koalas like Danny keep warm to PO Box 3028, Plympton Park, South Australia, 5038.
description: A curious koalas been left looking very naked and very unimpressed after a run-in with a bowl of motor oil led to a run-in with a razor. And now he needs our help.
